Can you reduce the mapping to something purely numeric that you can
test? That would be easier to express in a (programming language-based)
test case. Then you should pick a few (a very small number, if
possible) test images to eye-ball now and then to double check that
nothing's gone wrong.

Remember: you just need to test the mapping somehow; it doesn't have to
use the images as input/output.

*********** REPLY SEPARATOR ***********

On 1/9/2002 at 9:39 AM David V. Olivier wrote:
I use JUnit for about 90% of my code.  I would like to use it for 100%
but 
I consistently find automated testing of certain types of functionality

particular difficult to accomplish.  My work is in digital mapping, and
I 
find complex operations on large data sets problematic.

Let me give a specific example:

I am currently implementing functionality to warp satellite images from
one 
mapping projection to another.  The image is distorted according to a 
complex formula.  On a low level, I can test that for a given input my 
implementation of the formula provides the result I expect, but on a
higher 
level I haven't been able to automate verification of that the final
image 
is correct.  I have only been able to superimpose the result on a 
background map I know is correct and eyeball the results.

I would be curious to hear feedback from more experienced JUnit users
on 
approaches to testing this type necessarily complex behavior.   I know
that 
Mock Objects are used to simplify the testing of certain types of
otherwise 
problematic scenarios, but I have no first hand experience with them
and 
don't clearly see their applicability in a case like this.  Have others

found that there are certain areas where, in practice, they simply
don't 
apply JUnit as the ratio of effort to develop the test compared to
benefit 
gained by the test is too high (certainly the issue of testing GUIs has

received plenty of attention on this list)?

I dislike leaving gaps in my tests, particularly in coverage for the
most 
difficult functionality, as these are the areas most likely to contain
bugs.


David Olivier

Digital Mapping, Charting & Geodesy Analysis Program
